# Security Standard Operating Procedure ## S-1 Rules of Engagement and Escalation - An officer shall strive to de-escalate a situation wherever possible, every officer possesses the prerogative to escalate to a level which is fit to contain the issue and control the situation.
Escalation can be summarised into five levels: - 1. [bold]Presence.[/bold] One or more officer’s presence. - 2. [bold]Warning.[/bold] A verbal or written warning from an officer. - 3. [bold]Show of force[/bold]. An officer shows a non-lethal means of force to demonstrate a threat of forceful arrest. - 4. [bold]Non-lethal means of force.[/bold] An officer uses non-lethal force to arrest a crewmember. - 5. [bold]Lethal means of force.[/bold] An officer uses lethal force on a crewmember to mitigate immediate damage to life and station.
- If a warning has been given, inform the rest of security and keep record of the warning. If the offence warned about is repeated, escalation to level 3 or 4 is advised.
- If a person threatens the safety of the station or risk of limb for any crew member on the station, including their own, immediate escalation to level 4 or 5 is advised.
- If non-security personnel holds a non-lethal means of force in their possession and level 3 and below does not get them to stand down, immediate escalation to level 5 is advised.
- A higher alert level means security is given more tools to de-escalate and contain a situation. It’s advised to inform your closest command member to keep the alert levels updated.
## S-2 Equipment - The Warden and the HoS is responsible for handing out and recovering equipment as needed.
[textlink="Click here for a list of allowed equipment for each alert level." link="SecurityEquipmentSOP"]
## S-3 Uniform [bold]S-3-A[/bold] - Off Duty officers are officers that have signed on to shift as an officer however for various reasons are not acting as an officer. - Off Duty Officers may be permitted to carry a standard issue sidearm by the Head of Security or Warden, however may not use it unless under dire circumstances. - Off Duty Officers are not required to wear Security specific equipment.
[bold]S-3-B[/bold] - On Duty Officers are expected to operate as standard by SOP. - On Duty Officers must be clearly visible as officers through use of a standard Security Uniform.
[bold]S-3-C[/bold] - Cadets must at all times wear a red jumpsuit and security cap unless EVA operations must actively be performed.
[bold]S-3-D[/bold] - A Dress Officer is an On Duty Officer currently performing in a parade or big public display. - Dress Officers are required to wear the Parade Uniform or the most prestigious Security Officer uniform - Dress Officers may carry a sidearm in their pocket - Dress Officers may not wear bags, belts, or armour. - Dress Officers may carry a ceremonial sword in its sheath. - Dress Officers are permitted Longarms in a ceremonial non-functional fashion.
## S-4 Evidence [bold]S-4-A[/bold] - Detectives and the HoS are granted with the authority of handling and gathering evidence, however these may be delegated to officers to act on their behalf.
[bold]S-4-B[/bold] - Physical evidence is any item that may indicate past or future crimes with a reasonable suspicion. Anything within a reasonable radius of a crime scene may also be considered physical evidence. Contraband is always considered physical evidence.
[bold]S-4-C[/bold] - Physical evidence should be tampered with as little as possible and reasonably handled to not leave more fingerprints or fibres.
[bold]S-4-D[/bold] - Any officer may confiscate Physical Evidence and store it in an evidence locker with a brief record of the physical evidence.
[bold]S-4-E[/bold] - A testimony is a document that had been recorded with a tape recorder detailing a potential witness’ relation to a crime and the relevant information the witness saw. Testimonies should be concise and avoid needless speculation.
[bold]S-4-F[/bold] - A sophont may be considered a witness with reasonable suspicion, and can be compelled to provide a testimony.
[bold]S-4-G[/bold] - There is no expectation that all relevant evidence will be presented to the magistrate during pre-trial.
## S-5 Probable Cause - Probable cause means a lawful authority has sufficient knowledge of facts or evidence that would lead a reasonable person to believe that a crime has been, is, or will be committed.
## S-6 Arrests [bold]S-6-A[/bold] - An arrest is when an officer places under custody a crew member for the purpose of interrogation, processing, or immediate damage mitigation. An arrest may be performed with probable cause by any officer.
[bold]S-6-B[/bold] - An Arrest Warrant grants the permission for any member of security to execute an arrest on a target crewmember with suspicion of specific charges.
[bold]S-6-C[/bold] - An Arrest Warrant must be approved. It can be approved by the Magistrate and the CO. On Blue and Amber alerts it may instead be approved by the HoS.
[bold]S-6-D[/bold] - An arrest on Red, Delta, and Gamma alerts may be performed by any officer with reasonable suspicion of a charge.
## S-7 Personnel Searches [bold]S-7-A[/bold] - A personnel search is a temporary seizure of the objects in a crewmember's backpack, hands, coat, belt, and pockets. After the search is conducted all items besides evidence will be returned. A personnel search may be conducted by any officer with probable cause.
[bold]S-7-B[/bold] - Search Warrant is a document allowing an officer to search a person defined in the document with reasonable suspicion.
[bold]S-7-C[/bold] - A Search Warrant must be approved. It can be by the Magistrate and the CO. On Blue Alert, it may be approved by HoS.
[bold]S-7-D[/bold] - Personnel searches on Amber, Red, Delta, and Gamma alerts may be performed by any officer with reasonable suspicion.
## S-8 Department Searches [bold]S-8-A[/bold] - A departmental search is the sweep of an entire area or department for evidence.
[bold]S-8-B[/bold] - Departmental Search Warrant is a document allowing an officer to search a defined department thoroughly with probable cause of a crime.
[bold]S-8-C[/bold] - Departmental Search Warrants must be approved by the relevant head of that department or the CO. On Blue alert the Magistrate may approve as well as the HoS on Amber alert.
[bold]S-8-E[/bold] - Department searches on Red, Delta, and Gamma alert may be performed by any officer with reasonable suspicion.
